comments.commentBody: since Obama won the popular vote in the 2008 election, I'm guessing that the plurality of American voters in this country have some sort of the same affliction.
The greedy Democratic states want more and more of the taxpayers' money.  What else is new?

Great. More money for the rest of us. In fact, I think it's about time these red state governors get no federal money at all. Let them make ends meet on whatever taxes they collect within the state. Because they are all so ideologically (compared to rationally) opposed to taxes of any kind, that should be about $10.56/year.

Let's see how long they can keep it together on that.

Time to call the bluff of these big mouth braggarts and ideological clowns. If they want to talk tough, let's see how long they can last paying for it themselves.

The fact is that red states are overwhelming supported by blue states. Blue states pay for themselves AND all those right wing controlled states who spew so much hatred and vitriol their way. Fine. Let the blue states keep their tax money. Let the red states keep theirs. Then start the clocks ticking to see which states crumble first.

You want to talk the talk? Walk the walk. You'll be crawling soon enough.
Oh Great.  Skype has been working almost perfectly since it first launched.  Now Microsoft buys it and here come the bugs.  So long Skype.
Microsoft Skype? Can they screw up another great product? Let's hope not. I like skype.

I have a brilliant friend who's also, unfortunately and irritatingly, an anti-Semite. (Or rather, a half-anti-Semite: he likes Arabs well enough.) When I took the time to question his views instead of just asking him to spare me another recitation of them, he simply said, "I don't know a single Jew who doesn't support Israel, no matter what it does to the Palestinians." The best reply is of course, "You don't know enough Jews," but as a hyperbole, my friend has a point. It's not that there isn't a single Jew who seeks a more balanced view of Israeli actions (and U.S. support for them), but that the dissenters are usually drowned out by the kind of person my friend refers to.

Personally, I'm not anti-Israel: the country, besides being democratic, is a fait accompli, like North America, which was also appropriated from its natives. I'd just like to see more publicity like this affair (significantly decried by Dr. Fish) on behalf of critical (i.e., balanced) views of Israel. A few years ago, Israel tried to expel an ethnically Jewish family for the infraction of being closet Christians. This hardly seemed respectful to the religion of Israel's chief financial benefactor. I'm an agnostic but still feel this as an insult. I don't know whether or not Israel succeeded in deporting that poor family because I could find no more news about it. In the present case, I think the board member's influence was more than "dumb"; it was an attempt to punish and suppress a a dissenting view.

My father, who died in 1964, attended CCNY during the 1930's, and was a strong (read: vehement) fundraiser for the State of Israel during the late 1940's and 50's. He also supported AIPAC during that period. But he would have been horrified, as I am, at the anti-peace attitudes and actions of AIPAC and Bibi Netanyahu, and at CUNY's shameful behavior in this case, denying an honorary degree because the candidate wanted Israel to pursue a more honorable, more tolerant path in the pursuit of peace and justice.

AIPAC and Bibi feel that their way is the only way, and attack anyone with a different opinion as "anti-Israel". In truth there and are many possible courses open to Israel, some of which -- many of which -- do not entail as much killing. Jeffrey S. Wiesenfeld's attacks on Kushner, which totally misrepresented Kushner's positions, would still not have constituted an academically appropriate basis for denying the honorary degree, even if they were accurate.

Benno Schmidt should be ashamed for letting this occur during his watch.

I am sorry if this offends.  Sure he is an inspiration. But if this man has access to technology that simple mortals like myself can only dream about then why does he continue to use that "Speak and Spell" device for his voice.

Interesting article, but - like so much of what we think about the Civil War - is based too much in myth and exaggeration...

Few extant firms from the Civil War era continue to take a beating in the literature as does Brooks Brothers. Historian Stuart Brandes, an expert on war profiteering in American history, admits there were numerous problems with the early Brooks Brothers uniform contracts but justly concludes that, while they caused “much embarrassment to New Yorkers,” they did “no significant damage to the war effort.” He adds that “the matter hardly deserved the notoriety it received.”

Like shoe factories in Gettysburg and other Civil War myths, the illusion of Brooks Brothers as the archetypal Civil War profiteer endures: one recent biographer of Boss Tweed and his Tammany Hall machine states matter-of-factly (and incorrectly) that “none less than Brooks Brothers supplied twelve thousand sets of uniforms early in the war using ‘shoddy’ — ground up rags — that fell apart after a few days.” \

Perhaps the illusion endures because Brooks Brothers itself endures, but if it does it is for lack of facts, perspective, and historical context.

The fact is that only a fraction of the uniforms that Brooks Brothers supplied were made from (admittedly) substandard material and had to be replaced (at Brooks Brothers’ expense). In terms of perspective, Brooks Brothers can hardly be thought of as a chronic profiteer: apart from a few more contracts to supply the New York militia, it never became one of the premier suppliers to the Union Army. The historical context is also important. In the years between the world wars, the Army’s quartermasters still complained of the vagaries of supplying a large army with uniforms and pointed to the very problems that had plagued Brooks Brothers in the Civil War: securing large lots of uniform cloth of uniform color of durable fabric suitable for the rigors of campaign.

See:

Brandes, S. D. Warhogs: A History of War Profits in America. Lexington: University Press of Kentucky, 1997.pp. 71-72.

Ackerman, K. D. Boss Tweed: The Rise and Fall of the Corrupt Pol Who Conceived the Soul of Modern New York. New York: Carroll & Graf, 2005.p. 107.

(For brief notes on the historiography of the exaggerated claims against the Brooks Brothers uniforms, especially that they disintegrated in the rain, see Brandes, p. 307, n. 18)

Above is from my book, "Lincoln's Labels: America's Best Known Brands and the Civil War" (Edinborough Press, 2008), which includes a full chapter about Brooks Brothers and the Civil War.

Mr. Fish misses a key point.  I am a professor at a community college--academically speaking, a rung below John Jay.  If our board of regents decides to reconsider awarding an honorary degree under political pressure, from inside or out, what message does that send ME?  I do not dispute Mr. Fish's less expansive view of academic freedom.  But Mr. Fish seems to dwell in a world where he is free from such pressures, and I envy him.  Here in the real world, it's just a tad different.

Let's not wax poetic about the philosophical implications of the much awaited capture or killing of OBL. In the aftermath of having savored the writings of our admittedly incomparable writer, Mr. Çavett, and the many talented, thoughtful comments it evoked, it is difficult to stop such a course of thinking. However, let's not forget the simplicity of thought and intent which demanded justice for the utter horror of OBL's deed on 9/11, and all the other acts of wanton violence before and after that day.

Kudos to our President, the truly remarkable Navy Seals, and all those who had a hand in bringing about the demise of OBL!

As a Jew and a CCNY graduate who shared lunch room tables and rooms at Army Hall at CCNY uptown with holocaust survivors and who participated in a student walkout protesting the racist bigotry of Professors Davis and Knickerbocker, I believe CCNY (or CUNY) should not award an honorary degree to Tony Kushner.

Thank you Bittman for continuing to write about issues of the standard practice in factory farms. I'm coming to the comments late and have not read all of them -- many debate eating meat versus not, or eating humanely raised meat, etc. To me, the fundamental issue here that is so crucial is that MOST PEOPLE HAVE NO IDEA about how these animals are raised. I didn't, until I read The Omnivore's Dilemma and then started reading more and more. I kept asking myself, "Why didn't I know this?" Well, obviously I didn't know because "they" don't want me to know, they don't want anyone to know, because they know how absolutely horrified we'd all be, and that many of us would stop buying their tortured animal products.

This is why columns and discussions like this are so important. How can we get people who don't read the NY Times to find out about these issues?

Let us think about this ... nine percent unemployment and rising.  Commodity inflation on fire,  Expansion of two wars and the addition of a third brand new war that could last for many years.  Oh yes, this "community organizer" is turning out to be something really special

The USA declared war against Japan in 1941. The fact that Japan had already attacked didn't change that declaration. Japan was clearly the aggressor, but the USA did declare war.

Some Southerners no doubt remained neutral as long as they didn't feel threatened. When the North declared war, in response to Southern aggression, some Southerners felt threatened and decided to defend 'their' side. I don't think the remark makes the author 'pro-south.'

The Repubilcans are clowns - no question there. But Obama? Now he's Winston Churchill?

We do not know what will happen in Pakistan. Will this raid cause the government to fail, a radical regime to take its place and cut off our land access to Afghanistan?

There are dozens of scenarios that may play out in Pakistan, and 99% of them are bad. Sure, Obama's a gambler. But was killing one sick old unarmed man worth (1) endangering the stability of nuclear-armed Pakistan and (2) shredding our Constitution? I think not.

Good to see Arthur Reber, comment No. 23,  writing in from his retirement in Point Roberts, WA, up on the border of British Colombia.  A truly beautiful spot.  Arthur spent decades helping to build a better CUNY.  My question to him concerns why he is wasting his time reading Fish when he could be writing in defense of the attacks on CUNY by trustees like Weisenfeld.  The Kushner affair is the least of the dumb and damaging things Weisenfeld and his colleagues on the Board of Trustees have been up to. If anything good can come of this affair, it will be the opening of the Board of Trustees to public view generally.  If you care for CUNY, watch out.

I'm appalled that Stanley Fish would characterize Wiesenfeld's bullying of the board "business as usual." And he seems to miss Professor Schrecker's point about academic freedom- it's not Kushner's freedom that was violated, it was the board's- thus seizing the opportunity to defend a political appointee who just happens to be a rabid Zionist and is unafraid to use his cudgel wherever he sniffs out a "threat" to Israel.

In my view the root issue was debt and land, with a smaller degree of concern over inheritance law. The South's economy depended on slavery because there was no inflation in the mid-1800s. Because the northern states' economies were based on industry and small-scale farming the economy was growing faster than their debts. And the economy was growing faster than the supply of new silver and gold. That increased the value of the dollar and forced price deflation.

The Southern economy relied on debt to fuel large-scale agriculture investments, and agricultural productivity did not grow with the size of the economy. Price deflation caused by the industrial revolution in the North raised the value of debts, lowered the value of land and other assets, and put constant downward pressure on crop prices. The only way out was to get more free labor--and more free land. This is why the expansion of slavery into the West was the single great divisive issue, from 1820 onward. This is why southern aristocrats dreamed of taking over Mexico and Cuba. This is why the North's refusal to expand slavery into new states infuriated the South. This issue of debts, deflation and metal money was the underlying reason why the South refused to abandon slavery. It even made its way into Thomas Jefferson's original draft of the Declaration of Independence: he blames the King of England for slavery, because the King's banks would not allow inflation, which locked large-scale slaveowners into constant and increasing indebtedness.

If the United States had instituted paper money and a steady increase in the money supply matching the growth of the economy, it would have provided Southern slaveholders with a pathway out of debt, and a possibility of escaping the economic trap of slavery, without losing their land or their economic status.

But the North probably preferred war to inflation. And the huge population of slaves would have still caused a social and political crisis, starting with assertions by former slaves who were children of white men that they had a right to share in their fathers' inheritance. The resulting social conflict around this and many other social issues would have been aggressive and violent.

So slavery made a war of some sort necessary in the end, even if slavery was not the immediate cause or trigger. The war could have been delayed if the economy had grown much more slowly, for example. And if the country had allowed inflation it is possible that the war could have taken the form of a multi-decade social conflict instead of an acute crisis, and it's possible that the deaths might have numbered in the thousands instead of the hundreds of thousands.

Barack Obama learned other things on the South Side of Chicago -- not the least of which was retail politics. Nothing has infuriated li'l ole liberal me more than Obama's political arts, but he would not be president if not for them. During the 2008 campaign, Ryan Lizza wrote a much-hailed but little-read piece for the New Yorker in which he detailed how state senator Obama learned to jockey his district to his advantage and how to outsmart a popular Democratic rival.

I think it was the deliberateness and detail of Obama's youthful political moves that are most demonstrative of the deliberate and detailed way the older Obama went after Osama bin Laden. The same young man who labored in the bowels of Cook County records rooms to ferret out the most advantageous gerrymander was the man who grew up to labor in the Situation Room over the best method to catch a terrorist.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com
Thank God for President Obama!  This is a complex man, who is consistently maligned by people who have no clue.

There must be a hatchery somewhere, where the worst of these candidates gets to advance to the money round. Where's Mitt, and the dog tied to the roof of the car? Bet he wishes he never wrote that. Sorry Mitt it's all out there for everybody to see...
I can't see any of these Republicans getting elected dog catcher!

These excesses were the reason Lincoln requested, and Congress passed in 1863, the Civil False Claims Act, which provided penalties and fines for those contractors cheating the federal government. Almost 150 years later, the FCA is perhaps the government's (and private whistleblowers') strongest weapon to combat healthcare fraud, resulting in billions of dollars in recoveries to the government each year.
not as much pain as the loser fans suffer
Syria and Assad: partner for peace. Why would Israel have concerns to return the Golan Heights to such a paragon of peace and civility?
